title: Big four bank hit with record $240m fine over 'years' of misconduct
text:
ANZ has agreed to a record $240 million fine sought by Australia's financial services watchdog over ﻿years of "unconscionable conduct".

ASIC and ANZ will ask the federal court to impose the penalties in relation to four separate proceedings﻿.

These include acting "unconscionably" in dealing with the Australian government while managing a $14 billion bond deal, and incorrectly reporting its bond trading data to the government by overstating the volumes by tens of billions of dollars over almost two years.

ANZ has agreed to a record $240 million fine. (Will Willitts)

ASIC also accused ANZ of failing to respond to hundreds of customer hardship notices, in some cases for more than two ﻿years, and of failing to have proper hardship processes in place.

ANZ is also accused of making "false and misleading" statements about its savings interest rates, and failing to pay the promised rate to tens of thousands of customers.

The fourth proceeding involves allegedly failing to refund fees charged to thousands of dead customers, and not responding to loved ﻿ones trying to deal with deceased estates within the required time frame.

READ MORE: ﻿ Teacher killed as sea biscuit ride turned to tragedy

ASIC Chair Joe Longo. (Peter Rae)

"Time and time again ANZ betrayed the trust of Australians," ASIC chair Joe Longo said.

"The total penalties across these matters are the largest announced by ASIC against one entity and reflect the seriousness and number of breaches of law, the vulnerable position that ANZ put its customers in and the repeated failures to rectify crucial issues."

He said ANZ had shown an "unacceptable" disregard for the trust of customers and the government.

"In the bond trading case, ANZ was in a trusted position and its conduct had the potential to reduce the amount of funding available to the government. This funding is used to support critical services including Australia's health and education systems, affecting all Australians," Longo said.

"When public funds are put at risk, every Australian pays the price."

ANZ chairman Paul O'Sullivan. (Jamila Toderas)

The court will determine whether the proposed penalties for each matter are appropriate.

ANZ will implement a program to address the allegations by ASIC, as well as a $150 million "root cause remediation program" to identify the weaknesses across the company that led to the errors.

"While we have worked hard to get regulatory certainty on these matters, the reality is we made mistakes that have had a significant impact on customers," ANZ chair Paul O'Sullivan said.

"On behalf of ANZ, I apologise and assure our customers we have taken the necessary action, including holding relevant executives accountable."

ANZ said it had not been accused of market manipulation in rel﻿ation to the government bonds.

title: Western Australia to receive two extra public holidays
text:
R﻿esidents of Western Australia will receive two extra days off under an overhaul of the state's public holiday calendar.

The revamped schedule will include ﻿a new weekday public holiday, known as Show Day, to coincide with the first Monday of the September-October school holidays.

The other new day off will be Easter Saturday, bringing WA into line with other mainland states which already have the day as an official holiday, along with Good Friday, Easter Sunday and Easter Monday﻿.

READ MORE: How to maximise public holidays and make the most of your annual leave in 2025

Residents of Perth and the rest of WA will be receiving two extra public holidays. (Hamish Hastie) (Nine)

Other changes include shifting WA Day from June to ﻿the second Monday in November when the weather is usually sunnier.

But residents will still enjoy a winter day off, with the King's Birthday public holiday will moving to the second Monday in June from September.

The shake-up will also mean a change in the date of Labour Day to the second Monday in March to better align with other states. In state election years, this will be tweaked by holding the public holiday on the third Monday in March, to avoid holding an election on a long weekend.

The changes mean WA will have a total of 13 public holidays every year, the same as ﻿Victoria and the ACT.

The new schedule for public holidays will be introduced into state parliament this week, with a planned rollout in 2028.

The WA government says it received 10,000 submissions from community groups, businesses and members of the public before it announced the reforms.

Premier Roger Cook says the changes are about ﻿"modernising" the WA public holiday calendar to better serve the community.

"By adding two new public holidays – Easter Saturday and Show Day – we're creating a schedule that better matches the rhythm of life in WA," he said.

"And by realigning three existing ones, we are supporting productivity and economic activity across the state."

title: Motorsport rocked by death of much-loved competitor and father
text:
The South Australian motorsport community has been rocked by the death of a much-loved father and competitor.

Father-of-two Shane Mann, 50, died after suffering a medical episode in the support paddock of the AirTouch 500 at The Bend Motorsport Park yesterday.

Mann was a driver in the ﻿Aussie Racing Cars category.

Father-of-two Shane Mann, 50, died after suffering a medical episode in the support paddock. (9News)

The incident was unrelated to his car.﻿

Aussie Racing Cars race two was cancelled after Mann's death.﻿

His beloved number 21 car led the grid on its formation lap earlier today.

The front row of the grid for race three was left vacant in Mann's honour too.

The tight-knit Australian racing community is feeling the impact of Mann's sudden death.

His beloved number 21 car led the grid on its formation lap earlier today. (9News)

Mann has been described as a "true racer at heart" in a statement shared by Aussie Racing Cars.

"Shane wasn't just﻿ a competitor, he was a husband, father, friend and smiling face," the statement reads.

"His passion and presence will be deeply missed."

title: Eye disease supplement found to have anti-cancer effect
text:
A﻿n over-the-counter supplement used to treat an eye disease has been found to potentially have anti- cancer properties.

The dietary supplement slowed tumour growth and boosted the effects of immunotherapy to destroy cancer in tests on mice.

﻿Susan Rau has been taking a supplement every day for the past 10 years to slow the progression of her macular disease, which impacts up to two million Australians.

﻿Susan Rau has been taking a supplement every day for the past 10 years. (9News)

"My mother had late stage macular disease and she had lost quite a lot of her central vision as a result," Rau told 9News.﻿

One of the key ingredients is zeaxanthin.

It's found naturally in dark leafy vegetables and many other foods including corn, tangerines and egg yolks.

That same nutrient, commonly used to protect vision, could also help the immune system fight cancer.

Researchers from the University of Chicago identified zeaxanthin in a large library of other nutrients and compounds.

One of the key ingredients is zeaxanthin. (9News)

In mice, the dietary supplements slowed tumour growth and when combined with immunotherapy, the effects were more significant, according to the researchers.

Experts here in Australia are curious.

"I think the results are really interesting, but all we know at the moment is it has been tested in mice and in cells in the laboratory," said Lifehouse Cancer Centre Associate Professor Kate Mahon.

"It'll be great to see it has a benefit in humans but we really need to test that in clinical trials first to find that out."﻿

title: Brawling NRL fans could face lifetime ban, Minns says
text:
Spectators involved in a brawl between rival fans during an NRL finals match in Sydney may face lifetime bans, NSW Premier Chris Minns says.

Police are investigating after supporters traded blows during the Cronulla Sharks and Sydney Roosters elimination final at Shark Park last night.

Officers and stewards were forced to step in to separate the brawling fans inside the stadium.

Police are investigating a brawl between NRL fans at Shark Park in Sydney. (Nine)

A punch was thrown at one fan's head and a young girl was knocked to the ground in the tussle.﻿

NSW Premier Chris Minns today said it was a "disgraceful" to see such a display at a rugby league match.

"﻿To see a couple of thugs punch on at the football ... it's disgraceful," Minns said.

"So the police will throw the book at you, you might face lifetime bans and someone who loves their football team may never see the inside of a football stadium again if they carry on like that."﻿

Police are investigating..

"An investigation is underway after a brawl involving up to 10 people broke out within the grounds of a football stadium in Cronulla last night," NSW Police said.

"Police have commenced inquiries into the circumstances surrounding the incident."

The NRL said they were working with authorities to find those responsible, and threatened bans to anyone found guilty of offences.

"The NRL is working with both the venue and NSW Police regarding the incident. All supporters who attend NRL games are subject to the NRL Spectator Code of Conduct", an NRL spokesperson told 9News.

"Anyone found breaching the required standards can expect to be subject to significant sanctions, including being banned from venues."﻿

Cronulla Sharks boss Dino Mezzatesta stood firm too.

"Once those people have been identified, they will not be welcome back," he said.

title: AFL announces State of Origin return with WA-Vic clash confirmed
text:
The AFL has announced the return of State of Origin football for the first time in 27 years.

AFL chief executive Andrew Dillon confirmed Western Australia would host Victoria at Perth Stadium on February 14 in a standalone exhibition game.

It will mark the first true state vs state AFL match played since 1999, when Victoria defeated South Australia at the MCG.

Victoria and Western Australia haven't played each other since 1992.

"State football is one of the great traditions of our game, with fans and players alike calling for its return for some time and we are thrilled to see it back," Dillon said.

"Origin inspires passion, state pride and draws upon years-old rivalries that are central to the history of our game and our very greatest players."

Glen Jakovich alongside AFL chief executive Andrew Dillon at the AFL Origin announcement. (ABC News: Briana Shepherd)

The AFL has played a number of similar matches this century, including a 2008 Victoria vs Dream Team match and a 2020 Victoria vs All Stars charity game.

This year, an Indigenous All Stars team played Fremantle at Perth Stadium and drew a strong crowd.

Dillon has long been on record with his desire to bring back State of Origin and other marquee fixtures to extend the league's offering beyond the traditional seasons.

ABC/wires

title: Breaking: SANFL administrator Max Basheer dies aged 98
text:
Max Basheer — the football administrator who oversaw the creation of the Adelaide Crows and the purpose-built stadium Football Park — has died aged 98.

Basheer safeguarded the SANFL through crisis after crisis, eventually emerging with two of Australia's leading AFL teams.

He was born in Adelaide in 1927, raised in the timber town of Kalangadoo in the state's South East, and lined up as a footballer at Prince Alfred College.

Despite his successful start as a lawyer, Basheer found a passion for the tribunals of Australian rules football.

During his decades overseeing the SANFL, he orchestrated the sport's move from cricket-dominated Adelaide Oval to the brand new Football Park at West Lakes, including a long battle for the right to play there under lights.

"We had a judicial inquiry, we had a royal commission no less, and we finished up in the Supreme Court, and that was six and a half years after we started," he told the ABC in 2003.

Basheer with AFL legend Kevin Sheedy. (Instagram: SANFL)

More drama emerged in the early 1990s when the Port Adelaide Football Club attempted to defect to the AFL.

Basheer's SANFL emerged victorious with its own AFL team, the Adelaide Crows, but the Power did eventually follow.

He attended the final SANFL match at Football Park ahead of football's return to the Adelaide Oval.

"If it's for the better of football to move to Adelaide Oval, if there's a lot more money to be made for the two AFL clubs and the SANFL, I think we all have to support it," he said.

Basheer has been honoured in the AFL Hall of Fame, and with the naming of a stand at Adelaide Oval.

A legal legacy

His former firm DBH Lawyers said Basheer was a "much-loved and respected" member of the legal profession, and that his death had been received with "great sadness".

"Max was a cornerstone of our practice, then known as Duncan Basheer Hannon, until his retirement in 2019 at the age of 92," managing partner Amy Nikolovski said.

"His distinguished career was marked by integrity, dedication, and an unwavering commitment to serving his clients and community."

Basheer was raised in the timber town of Kalangadoo. (DBH Lawyers)

DBH said Basheer would be remembered "with gratitude and admiration for the legacy he leaves behind".

"Across more than six decades in the law, Max earned the respect of colleagues, adversaries, and clients alike," Ms Nikolovski said.

"He was renowned for his sound judgement, calm presence, and enduring contribution to South Australia's legal profession and to the football community as the longest serving Administrator of the SANFL."

The company extended its condolences to Basheer's friends and family, including "his daughters Jayne and Ann, and granddaughters Sophie and Georgie who he was so proud of and who brought his greatest joy".

Peter Humphries said his family were close friends with the Basheer family in Kalangadoo before the pair worked together in the same law firm later in life.

"I've literally grown up knowing Max virtually [since] the day I was born," Mr Humphries said.

"He was one of these people that was well known and well liked.

"Back in the day when he was still involved in football, walking along the street with him, you took a long time to get anywhere because everyone to say hello to him."

Mr Humphries said Basheer died on Sunday night.

title: Outback ringmaster takes boxing tent to Birdsville for the last time
text:
Not everyone has heard of Fred Brophy's Boxing Troupe, but for those who have, it's an institution.

He'll sell you a ticket, spin you a yarn and dare you into the ring.

For more than four decades, fourth-generation showman Fred Brophy has been carting his boxing tent and fighters to Birdsville, one of the most remote towns in the country, as part of its annual races.

But this year's event, held earlier this month, marked the last time he would bring his tent.

The crowd was electric at the final show at the Birdsville Races. (Supplied: Peter Wallis)

Final showdown

In his signature red shirt, on the edge of the Simpson Desert, he stands on a raised platform, beating a bass drum with ritual certainty.

"Who wants a fight," he spruiks.

Courageous punters throw up their hands and a bell clangs as they're chosen.





Brophy's grandchildren were in Birdsville for the last show. (Supplied: Peter Wallis) It's part circus, part showdown, part spectacle — but now these boxing bells have tolled for the last time.

"There comes a time when enough's enough," Brophy said.

"I'm 73, when I'm getting up on that ladder, I can't do it like I used to."

Brophy said he was cutting back on shows and did not take his tent to New South Wales or Victoria anymore because of government regulations.





Fred Brophy is a legend in outback Queensland. (Supplied: Peter Wallis) But as long as he could get up the ladder, he said he would keep entertaining.

"When I go it will be a part of Australia that's gone but don't worry, I'll be around for a while," he said.

"I'm lucky like a cat, I've got nine lives."

Boxing in Birdsville

The Birdsville Races have attracted crowds of thousands to the far south-west of Queensland for 143 years.





Fred Brophy at the Birdsville Races in 1990. (Supplied: State Library of Queensland) For about 42 of those, Brophy has pitched his tent across from the pub.

Henry Butler grew up in Birdsville, and the 25-year-old Wangkangurru man remembers how it felt as a kid watching the town of 100 explode.

At a young age, he fell in love with the spectacle of the boxing tent.

"We used to sneak over and listen to the drum, watch all the fighters pop up," he said.

"One time, I think I was around 10, Fred looked at us and said, 'I reckon these two young fellas should get up and have a fight'."

Henry and his cousin had a crack on the mats and made $600 from the crowd throwing in coins.

"It's something I never forgot," Henry said.

Henry was sent to boarding school more than 1,000 kilometres away in Yeppoon, so it was years before he made it back to Brophy's.

"Every year Freddie was like, 'It's going to be my last year [in Birdsville],' Henry said.





Henry Butler (kneeling in front) with the boxing troupe from Birdsville. (Supplied: Peter Wallis) "That went on for a few years," he laughed.

Last year, Henry donned the robes for Brophy and this year he stepped into the ring for a final fight in his home town.

"People think all we're doing is just boxing but you have to be there to see and understand it," he said.

"It's one of the best experiences I've ever had.





Some people train all year to take on Fred Brophy's fighters. (Supplied: Peter Wallis) "The main reason I love it is the atmosphere: the crowds, everyone is singing along, getting along, having a beer together and then they jump in the ring, but after everyone is having a beer and a good yarn together."

End of an era

Gary Brook's family owns a large cattle station near Birdsville and runs the town's annual races.

Mr Brook, 44, has not missed a single year.





Fred Brophy and Gary Brook at a special Q&A session at this year's races. (Supplied: Peter Wallis) "I've never looked out from the pub and not seen his [Brophy's] tent," he said.

"It's going to be a strange feeling in years to come.

" It's a great loss that he's called time, but we can understand it. "

But even if the tent never returns, Brophy himself won't be staying away.

Wedding wager on Birdsville Cup win Photo shows A man and woman smiling in front of a famous troupe poster. A history-making Birdsville Races sees record prize money up for grabs, and potentially the end of a lengthy marital wager.

"I want to come back and see what they're going to do here and be able to relax … without worrying about the tent getting blown down in the wind."

And of course, there's the long-standing wager with his partner Sandy that she'll marry him if he either gives up drinking or wins a Birdsville Cup.

Although a celebrant was on hand, his horse Victory Bay didn't win this year, but maybe next year he'll have more luck.

"It's the biggest and the best event that happens in the outback," Brophy said.

Even though his tent won't be returning to Birdsville, Fred Brophy will be. (Supplied: Peter Wallis)

It seems the tent stands only while Brophy does, and when he hangs up the gloves, the last boxing tent of its kind in Australia will stay down for good.

title: Agritourism expansion leaves NSW winery facing $150,000 land tax bill
text:
Third-generation winemaker Jacob Stein has recently learned he is no longer considered a primary producer, and is now facing the prospect of a yearly land tax bill of $150,000.

He said his family's property at Mudgee, in the NSW Central West, had been exempt from the charge for almost 50 years.

"They're considering us not to be primary producers anymore, which we think is just absurd," Mr Stein said.

"We have a 600-acre [243-hectare] farm … we have wine, grapes, cattle, sheep, free-range pigs.

"We also have a winery where we produce wine, we have a cellar door and also a restaurant on site.

"[But] I still very much consider us farmers … [I'm] looking down on my work boots at the moment."

Jacob Stein is a third-generation Mudgee winemaker. (ABC Rural: Lucy Thackray)

Land tax is a New South Wales levy usually applied to properties that are not the owner's primary place of residence.

Property used for primary production is exempt from the tax, but a recent decision by the NSW Civil and Administrative Tribunal (NCAT) has shifted the goalposts for some farmers.

NCAT ruled that where wine sales generated more revenue than grape sales, the predominant purpose shifted from primary production (grape cultivation) to manufacturing (wine production), disqualifying the property from the land tax exemption.

A winery's classification depends on whether it makes more money selling wine or grapes. (ABC News)

Statewide impact

Wineries across regions such as Mudgee, the Hunter and the Central West have been investing in agritourism, encouraged by the Destination NSW Tourism Strategy.

NSW Wine chief executive Matthew Jessop said the reinterpretation of land tax rules "runs counter to all other government policy".

"It puts NSW at odds with all the other states, it certainly puts our farmers and grape growers at a big disadvantage," he said.

Some winemakers have claimed the reinterpretation puts NSW winemakers at a "significant disadvantage". (Stateline )

"Destination NSW and the Minister for Tourism, one of their strategic pillars is diversified agritourism businesses, because they know they create jobs and they create vibrant regional businesses."

Revenue NSW has denied any reinterpretation of the Primary Production Land tax exemption.

In a statement to the ABC, a spokesperson said no legislative changes relevant to the exemption had been made in 20 years.

"Rural land is exempt from land tax if the dominant use of the land is for a primary production purpose," they said.

"If a business owner, such as a wine grower, offers other products or services, such as a cellar door or restaurant, whether an exemption applies will depend on whether primary production is the dominant use of the land."

NSW Small Business Minister Janelle Saffin said it sounded as though wineries had diversified into other business areas.

"It also sounds like the primary producers' grant — if you get over 50 per cent of your income off farm, then you're not eligible for certain things and it's in that same category," she said.

"A lot of people diversify within their industry, and it depends where they get it."

Ms Saffin said she would "look into" the situation.

title: Port Hinchinbrook marina full of mud despite $1.5m dredging project
text:
There are calls for more dredging work at the embattled Port Hinchinbrook marina in north Queensland, despite the latest project failing to improve accessibility.

Exacerbated by natural disasters and red tape, mud and silt have choked the channel originally dug in the 1990s to provide access to the Great Barrier Reef.

Small businesses and the fishing industry in nearby Cardwell fear the situation is getting worse, as visitor and boat numbers continue to fall.

But conservationists say dredging is expensive, has not worked, and threatens endangered dugongs that feed in the area.

Digging for answers

In 2024, Cassowary Coast Regional Council acquired a licence to dredge up to 1,000 tonnes of mud and silt from the main canal, funded by a $1.5 million grant from the federal government.

That project was completed in January 2025, but by February, major flooding once again filled the port with debris.

"We undertook some flood debris clean-up, so that was actually separate to the dredging. The clean-up was completed in April," Mayor Teresa Millwood said.

Ralph Cremer says the mud is "very destructive" to vessels. (ABC Far North: Sophie Johnson)

But Ralph Cremer, a senior advisor with boat servicing business Port Hinchinbrook Marine, said the build-up of mud made the channel shallow and dangerous.

"At low tide, it's just full mud. You can't even move a boat on it, so it is very, very destructive to vessels," he said.

"Missing high tide if [fishermen] are in the channel, they can sit on the mud and go nowhere.

"If they're out in the ocean, they'll just have to wait until the tide comes back up so they can come in."

Boat moorings remain empty in the marina at Port Hinchinbrook. (ABC Far North: Sophie Johnson)

He said that made it unattractive for commercial operators, and as a result, the number of vessels in the shipyard had halved since Cyclone Yasi devastated the area in 2011.

"All the skippers or the owners of the vessels seem to lose the appetite to come to Port Hinchinbrook, either to the marina or the marine area itself," Mr Cremer said.

"It's just not commercial anymore to come into this channel."

Chris Mackay says the recent work has not improved safety. (ABC Far North: Sophie Johnson)

The council's project was well short of the $20 million a 2023 feasibility study estimated it would cost for a long-term dredging and maintenance plan.

Cardwell recreational fisherman Chris Mackay said he was concerned it had not improved safety.

"There's that much debris in the water or in the mud that you, you got to be clearing the mud with your propeller," he said.

Mario Dimauro, also a keen recreational fisherman, moved to Cardwell five years ago.

Mario Dimauro says the state of Port Hinchinbrook has worsened since he moved to Cardwell. (ABC Far North: Sophie Johnson)

He agreed access had worsened.

"When I first came here, 0.9 [metre] tide, you could get back in, now it's 1.8," Mr Dimauro said.

"It needs a total dredge out from the mouth back and then maintenance all the time.

" You can't just dredge it, cause it'll just fill in again. It's got to be maintained periodically. "

Deeper solutions

Retired engineer and local environmentalist John Mewing said dredging was not the solution.

John Mewing says the ongoing dredging of Port Hinchinbrook is prohibitively expensive. (ABC News: Baz Ruddick)

He said the recent project was not productive.

"What they've done there is going to refill with sediment, in a relatively short space of time," he said.

" We're going to be back to square one again. "

He said the Hinchinbrook channel had high siltation rates, meaning as water flowed in and out, it naturally dropped large amounts of sediment, making it "prohibitively expensive" to maintain.

Vessels are unable to get in and out of the water for most of the day from Port Hinchinbrook. (ABC Far North: Sophie Johnson)

Environmentalist Kenn Parker opposed the original dredge that made way for the development in the 1990s, which he said threatened endangered dugongs.

"Their feed areas along the western side of the channel, the seagrass beds have mostly disappeared … because of the release of the material from the spoil ponds," he said.

He said fewer boats in the area also made it a safer habitat for the animals.

In its first budget in June, the new LNP state government announced it was allocating funding "to enable delivery of options for the ongoing sustainable use of the port" but did not disclose how much it would spend.

Katter's Australian Party member for Hinchinbrook Nick Dametto said he was working with all levels of government for a long-term solution to the situation.

He said it was complicated by the legal status of the property, which made it unattractive to potential investors.

Nick Dametto and then-premier Steven Miles survey the silted waterway at the Port Hinchinbrook development in 2024. (Supplied)

"It was written in such a way where the developer basically became responsible for every single thing … the dredging, the roads, the sewerage," he said.

"A developer has not got the ability to rate and charge for any of those services.

"The way to solve the problem moving forward … [is] to replace parts of the development with a basic infrastructure agreement, for example, a long-term dredging plan."

title: Live: Severance leads Emmys as Adolescence star makes history
text:
Severance and The Pitt have won some of the first awards of the night at the 77th Annual Emmy Awards, while comedies Hacks and The Studio have also taken home gold.

Meanwhile, 15-year-old Owen Cooper has become the youngest person to win Best Actor in an Anthology for his performance in Adolescence.

Follow our live blog for all the winners, losers and key moments from television's biggest night.

title: Litchfield stars and Healy returns as Australia beats India in World Cup warm-up
text:
Phoebe Litchfield's boundary-laden knock has helped Australia romp to an eight-wicket victory in the opening one-day international against India in New Chandigarh.

India won the toss and elected to bat, setting Australia 282 in the first of three one-dayers serving as warm-up games for the ODI World Cup starting later this month.

But the hosts, having posted 7- 281 in their 50 overs, were clinically overhauled by the Australians, led by Litchfield as she cracked 14 fours in an 80-ball 88, while Beth Mooney (77*) and Annabel Sutherland (54*) also carded unbeaten half-centuries to steer the chase home.

Earlier, India openers Smriti Mandhana (58) and Pratika Rawal (64) and then Harleen Deol (54) also went past the 50 mark for India.

Deol came in at three after a 114-run opening stand and eventually became the first of two victims to Megan Schutt (2-45), who became the ninth Australian woman to play 100 one-day internationals.

Richa Ghosh (25) and Radha Yadav (19) added valuable runs down the Indian order while Deepti Sharma was unbeaten on 25 in the face of tight bowling from Ellyse Perry (0-15), Sutherland (1-31) and Georgia Wareham (0-36).

All up, Australia used eight bowlers, with only opening seamer Kim Garth (1-56) completing her full complement of 10 overs during the team preparation for its first World Cup clash with New Zealand on October 1 in Indore.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

Australia captain and opener Alyssa Healy, playing her first international since the Ashes Test against England ended on February 1, looked determined to take the game to India before she fell to all-rounder Kranti Goode for 27 off 23.

But then it was time for Litchfield, next backed up by Perry, to really impose herself on the game as she reached her half-century from 44 deliveries.

Perry's contribution was ended early when the 34-year-old was forced to retire with a calf cramping on 30, but player of the match Litchfield maintained the momentum until she fell 12 runs short of a third one-day century when caught off Sneh Rana.

That left Mooney and Sutherland to see the visitors past the target, reaching 2-282 in 44.1 overs with 35 balls to spare, in what was the fourth-highest run chase in women's one-dayers.

The ABC of SPORT Sports content to make you think... or allow you not to. A newsletter delivered each Saturday.

AAP

title: Wineries, distilleries worry about costs to add bottles to deposit scheme
text:
Winemakers and distillers are concerned the West Australian government's expanded trash for cash recycling scheme will increase costs for family-run businesses.

Under changes to WA's Container Deposit Scheme, announced by the premier last week, people will be able to receive a 10-cent refund for wine and spirit bottles from mid-2026.

The government said more than 4.5 billion containers had been collected since the scheme was rolled out for other drink manufacturers, including breweries and soft drink companies, in 2020.

The expansion will include glass wine and spirit bottles, cask wine and water, fruit and vegetable juices, flavoured milk and cordials.

Wine producers will pay to be part of the mandatory scheme. (ABC South West WA: Anthony Pancia)

The scheme is funded by beverage producers, with suppliers paying about 15 cents per container to cover the cost of refunds and operating the scheme.

The ABC has spoken to several breweries involved in the scheme which said there were significant additional costs associated with printing new labels, administration and compliance.

Administrative 'burden'

More than 25 million bottles of Margaret River wine are sold around Australia each year.

Multiplied by 13.84 cents per glass container, excluding GST, the ABC has calculated the local industry would pay at least $3.46 million per year directly to the scheme.

Margaret River Wine Association chief executive Amanda Whiteland said the real cost could be a lot higher.

"When you add in all the administrative costs of executing the scheme, as it's currently unique in every state, it could be up to $1 a bottle … that could be up to $25 million it could cost the industry a year," she said.

Amanda Whiteland says it could cost the local industry millions a year to comply. (Supplied: Amanda Whiteland)

" [It] puts a huge administrative burden back on producers. "

Queensland has added wine bottles to its container scheme and other states are set to follow suit.

More expensive wine and spirits

Bunbury-based distiller Rory Binnie said being given one year to adjust was hard to take when producers were already battling rising costs.

Rory Binnie says the cost and administrative burden will hit small producers hard. (ABC South West WA: Bridget McArthur)

"The concept is a really good idea … however, the timeframe [for the] 10-cent refund … is a little bit of a kick in the guts," he said.

"We're getting to a spot now where wineries and distilleries are looking to export because it's more affordable to sell bottles overseas than it is in Australia."

Beverage suppliers brought into the expansion will have to add a 10-cent refund notice to labels and ensure every product has a unique barcode.

Mr Binnie said it would be a significant additional cost for some companies who did not put labels on small-batch products they sold on site.

South West distiller Greg Garnish said it was also a blow to those who printed labels in bulk.

He said he recently printed $20,000 worth of new labels which would be out of date in nine months.

WA's Containers for Change program is set to include wine and spirit bottles. (ABC News: Courtney Withers)

"[But] it's a great initiative just to save the environment," Mr Garnish said.

Mr Binnie said it was just another factor placing strain on the industry, which he said was a big part of the South West's tourism sector and economy.

He said many businesses would pass those additional costs on to consumers, and called for more support from the government for local producers and more time to adjust.

Stakeholders consulted, government says

WA Environment Minister Matthew Swinbourn said it was important producers of single-use products took responsibility for the life of their containers.

"The Containers for Change scheme means both consumers and producers are invested in that responsibility to ensure these products do not end up in landfill," he said.

" The wine and spirit sector has been exempted from this shared responsibility for five years. "

Matthew Swinbourn says it's important producers and consumers share the cost. (ABC News: Keane Bourke)

Mr Swinbourn said the Department of Water and Environmental Regulation had consulted with key stakeholders, including the wine and spirit industry.

He said there would be a transition period for labels to be changed and small producers would have the option to report less often to reduce the administrative burden.

title: 'You're allowed to headbutt': Stuart's complaint rings true as Walsh dodges ban
text:
Superstar Broncos fullback Reece Walsh will be free to play in the NRL preliminary final after avoiding suspension for a headbutt on Hudson Young in Brisbane's epic win on Sunday.

Walsh was charged with grade-one striking for the incident in the 53rd minute of the electric contest that Brisbane eventually won 29-28 in golden point.

Walsh can accept a $3,000 fine with an early guilty plea and line up in the grand final qualifier against Canterbury or Penrith, but would be banned for two matches if he tried to fight the charge at the judiciary.

The 23-year-old also copped an $1,800 contrary conduct fine for flipping the bird at Canberra fans as he walked up the tunnel to the sin bin.

Walsh flipped the bird at the Canberra crowd as he went to the sin-bin. (Supplied: Kayo Sports)

Stand-in captain at Carrigan was not so lucky, facing a one- to two-match ban for a high shot on Morgan Smithies.

Both players spent time in the sin-bin as the Raiders built a 28-12 lead before Walsh returned with 18 minutes left in regulation and orchestrated a stunning comeback, culminating in a 94th-minute, game-winning field goal by Ben Hunt.

Hunt field goal seals Broncos heist after bunker denies Raiders Photo shows Ben Hunt celebrates his game-winning field goal with teammates Jamal Fogarty scores a try in golden point to send the Raiders to a preliminary final only for it to be disallowed before Ben Hunt delivers a dagger field goal.

The mercurial Broncos fullback scored one try, set up another and kicked a booming 40/20 to give Brisbane the ball for a third before hitting the crossbar with a long-range field goal attempt that would have tied the game, instead earning a penalty goal to send it to extra time when Zac Hosking ran through his kicking leg on his second attempt as the siren sounded.

For all the good he did, his afternoon will also be remembered for pushing his head into Young's face as the pair became entangled when the Raiders enforcer celebrated in his face after a Broncos knock-on.

Both players were sin-binned over the incident, with referee Ashley Klein dismissing Young for getting in Walsh's face, "which makes him react like that".

Reece Walsh and Hudson Young were sin-binned for this altercation. (Supplied: Fox Sports)

Walsh told Fox Sports after the game that his phenomenal final few minutes were repayment to his teammates after the Raiders scored twice during his period in the bin.

"I had to come out with something because getting sent for 10 in a bloody final, I was disappointed in myself," he said, joking that Young called him a "weak-gutted dog" in reference to Stuart's dig at Penrith's Jaeman Salmon in 2022.

Ricky Stuart said he did not want to focus too much on the officiating, but was clearly unhappy. (Getty Images: Mark Nolan)

Young and Raiders captain Joe Tapine protested on the field, and in the post-match press conference Stuart was adamant Walsh should have been sent off.

"They've set a precedent now. You're allowed to headbutt," Stuart said.

"If Joe or Hudson headbutted Reece Walsh what do you think would have happened?"

"They got it 100 per cent wrong," he added, while saying he did not want to steal focus from an incredibly entertaining contest.

Broncos coach Maguire tried to downplay the clash immediately after the game.

Walsh grabs the Sun to light up Brisbane's season Photo shows A man celebrates after winning a rugby league match Brisbane and Canberra went to the great beyond in their golden point finals match and it was Reece Walsh who led the Broncos to the promised land.

"I'd have to have a look at it. They were at each other a little bit," he told reporters.

"It was probably more just conversation, we'll have a look at it down the track.

"There is emotion out there. They were both sent for a reason, so you move on."

The incident is the second time Walsh has been accused of a headbutt in his career, with the Queenslander copping a grade-two striking charge for one in State of Origin in 2023.

Three minutes after Walsh's effort, Carrigan joined him in the bin for a high tackle that left Smithies with a bloody lip, resulting in a grade-two careless high tackle charge.

Carrigan can accept a one-game ban with an early guilty plea, or risk being rubbed out for the preliminary and grand final if he fights the charge and loses.

As their teammates fell behind 28-12 while the game was 11 vs 12, Carrigan said he and Walsh chatted in the sin bin about launching the audacious comeback.

"The conversation was pretty clear, it was just let's get out there and have a crack," Carrigan said.

"He was just saying let's go after this game, let's get another shot … He's clear and he backs himself."

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

The Broncos earned the week off before a preliminary final against the Bulldogs or Panthers after the 94-minute marathon match that included two periods of extra time before the golden point period ended with Hunt's field goal.

The break will be much needed as gun prop Payne Haas played out the game with a heavily strapped left ankle.

There are also real concerns over second-rower Brendan Piakura, with fears he suffered a depressed cheekbone in the first half of Sunday's match.

The team is hopeful of having captain and halfback Adam Reynolds back from a hamstring strain for the preliminary final.

The ABC of SPORT Sports content to make you think... or allow you not to. A newsletter delivered each Saturday.

AAP/ABC

title: ANZ faces record penalty for ripping off customers and government
text:
ANZ bank faces a record $240 million penalty for engaging in "unconscionable conduct" in some of its bond trading for the federal government, as well as "widespread misconduct" affecting nearly 65,000 retail customers.

The bank has agreed to the penalty with the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC), although it will require Federal Court approval.

"Time and time again, ANZ has fallen short," ASIC's chair Joe Longo told a press conference on Monday.

"Time and time again, ANZ has betrayed the trust of Australians.

"Today many Australians will rightly be questioning their trust in ANZ."

The settlement includes $125 million over a specific trade in Australian government bonds on 19 April 2023, where ANZ was helping the country's sovereign debt management agency deliver $14 billion in bonds.

ASIC said where the bank misreported trading data and acted "unconscionably", and its actions had the potential to reduce the amount of funding available to the government.

"'We have looked very closely at what happened on the day," ANZ chair Paul O'Sullivan told an investor briefing about that trade this morning.

" We breached some of our license obligations. "

ASIC said that ANZ sold a large chunk of 10-year bond futures around the time the bond issue was priced, which placed downward pressure on bond prices and could have resulted in a shortfall in the bond sale.

ASIC said that, when the government later asked what had happened, the bank's answers were misleading or deceptive.

ANZ said that ASIC has not alleged it engaged in market manipulation or over-hedging.

The bank said all trading undertaken by ANZ as duration manager was to hedge the risk borne by it in connection with its role on this transaction.

ANZ claims that no loss was caused to the Commonwealth from its trading as duration manager.

ANZ is also alleged to have overstated its bond trading turnover for nearly two years, which may have resulted in it winning more appointments as the lead for future bond issues.

"We have apologised to the AOFM [Australian Office of Financial Management] for the inadequate communication on this transaction and offered to pay the AOFM the revenue ANZ earned as duration manager," Mr O'Sullivan in a statement.

" The board has driven comprehensive accountability reviews in relation to the markets issues, which have resulted in significant reductions in remuneration for certain current and former executives. "

Mr O'Sullivan told the investor briefing on Monday morning that it believes the bonds matter was now dealt with.

"We do believe today that this draws a line under those issues and lets us move forward," he said.

Nearly 30,000 customers underpaid savings interest

The regulator said $115 million of the proposed penalty relates to customer failings.

ANZ failed to respond to 488 customer hardship notices, in some cases for more than two years.

ASIC said that the reasons for the hardship applications included unemployment, serious health issues, bereavement and family violence.

In some cases, ANZ undertook debt collection activities, including issuing default notices and bringing in external debt collection agencies, despite not having responded to the customer's hardship application.

Separately, ANZ made false and misleading statements about some of its savings rates, failing to pay the promised introductory bonus interest rate to tens of thousands of customers.

ANZ had already compensated nearly 200,000 customers affected by this between July 2013 and January 2024, however ANZ is now remediating another 29,917 customers who were underpaid interest for similar reasons between August 2024 and March 2025.

The bank also failed to refund fees to thousands of dead customers and was slow in responding to loved ones trying to manage deceased estates.

As with the incorrect savings rates, ASIC said this was due to inadequate systems and processes that could not identify which fees should be waived or refunded, not whether any fees had already been waived or refunded.

ASIC said ANZ had already been penalised seven times in the past eight years for prior misconduct.

ANZ bosses say sorry

ANZ chair Paul O'Sullivan acknowledged the bank had "made mistakes that have had a significant impact on customers".

" On behalf of ANZ, I apologise and assure our customers we have taken the necessary action, including holding relevant executives accountable. "

Last week, ANZ's new chief executive Nuno Matos, who has only been in the role for a matter of months, announced the bank would be cutting 3,500 staff and around 1,000 contractor positions over the next year.

"The failings outlined are simply not good enough and they reinforce the case for change," he said in a statement.

"It is my expectation that we see measurable improvements across the bank to better protect and care for our customers and to create a more sustainable business."

title: Live: Sydney heat deaths to double even at global warming best-case scenario
text:
The Smart Energy Council says the National Climate Risk Assessment shows Australia must rapidly roll out renewable energy and put an end to new coal and gas projects.

The group says the the risk assessment confirms what everyone knows and fears.

Chief executive John Grimes has also called on the government to set an ambitious 2035 emissions reduction target.

"It's clear the time for talk has passed, the time for action on slashing carbon and methane gas is now," Grimes says.

"One of the best and most rapidly deployable methods of doing that, is through renewable energy, and along with our members we stand ready to make that happen."

title: Some WA doctors will soon start diagnosing ADHD, but parents have concerns
text:
Perth mum Sarah Jackson thinks her five-year-old daughter Ayla has ADHD, just like her older sister.

But she's been told it will be four years to get a diagnosis if she wants to wait in the public system.

Ms Jackson said that wait has had an emotional toll on her family.

"I don't know what the future holds for Ayla and that's … scary," Ms Jackson said.

"There's no early intervention for her."

Ayla is only five, and therefore is unable to be given an ADHD diganosis by a GP in WA. (ABC News)

Ayla will miss out on a new program that makes it easier to get an ADHD diagnosis.

In Western Australia, 65 general practitioners will be trained to diagnose and prescribe ADHD medication, but only for children older than 10.

"I was pretty disappointed and disheartened that she would be nine years old just to even get that first appointment," Ms Jackson said.

With Ayla set to start school next year, Ms Jackson said it has filled her family with uncertainty surrounding Ayla's education.

" I don't know what's going to happen between now and [age] nine with her learning and how she's going to cope. "

"It just puts her in limbo land because by the time she gets to the point of actually having the choice of a GP or the paediatrician ... It's going to be too late for her."

Difficulties diagnosing younger children

The Royal Australian College of GPs, which will train the specialist doctors, said caution is needed when diagnosing younger children.

Sean Stevens, from RACGP's WA branch said the college hasn't decided whether more training is required to diagnose children under 10.

"We feel that … there are difficulties in that cohort," Dr Stevens said.

Dr Sean Stevens says diagnosing patiends under 10 can be problematic. (ABC News: Lily Kristanto)

"At this stage we feel it's best with this training to focus on the 10 and up."

But the rules differ in each jurisdiction.

In Queensland, GPs are allowed to diagnose and prescribe ADHD medication for children as young as 4.

New South Wales, South Australia and the ACT will also train doctors to diagnose and treat the condition in children, but haven't specified at what age.

In Tasmania, more GPs and paediatricians are being recruited to deal with long waitlists.

Thousands on public waitlist

Through WA's public health system, psychologists can diagnose children with ADHD, and paediatricians are able to diagnose and prescribe ADHD medication for children.

Ayla was not given a wait time, but there are more than 12,000 children on WA's public waitlist to see a paediatrician for a range of conditions.

Ms Jackson said it affects a lot more than just the children.

Sarah Jackson says the long waiting lists to see health professionals is having a big impact on society. (ABC News)

"I know that there are families out there who are really struggling, who are on that wait list who aren't getting supported and they've had to quit their job," Ms Jackson said.

"Some of them, they just need help now, it's absolutely shocking."

" It's underestimated, the impact that that wait list is having on our society. Families need more support. "

Ms Jackson said going private was not an option financially.

Australia's most common ADHD drug has had a spike in adverse event reports Photo shows An illustration of a hot pink bill with blue and black liquid pouring out Australia's pharmaceuticals watchdog is investigating a spike in reports related to Vyvanse, the country's most commonly prescribed ADHD medication.

Peter Jones from Queensland's Bond University says paediatricians are struggling to meet demand.

He said the move to allow doctors to diagnose and prescribe ADHD medication is a good way to relieve the burden of long waitlists.

"The average age of the general paediatrician population is getting older, and we need to be able to work out how we can address this," Dr Jones said.

" It's a nationwide problem. "

He also thinks the age in WA should be lower, to allow GPs to make a diagnosis and consider the use of medication in school-aged children, but not for those in preschool.

Call for consistency

Industry bodies are calling for a nationally consistent approach to diagnosing and treating ADHD.

The Royal Australasian College of Practitioners' Paediatrics and Child Health President Niroshini Kennedy said a standardised approach would be more efficient.

She says it's important minimum standards are established.

Dr Niroshini Kennedy says national standards for ADHD diagnosis would make sense. (Supplied)

"We've got no doubt that there is a role for general practitioners in the diagnosis and treatment of ADHD," she said.

She said the support provided to both young people and the general practitioners needed to be standardised and of high quality.

AFLW star Emma O'Driscoll on using ADHD to her benefit Photo shows A woman does a cartwheel on a football field. The Fremantle Dockers star has found strength in having ADHD, especially on the football field. Can having neurodivergent traits like hyper-focus give athletes a real advantage?

Ms Kennedy said there needs to be publicly funded services for ADHD and other neurodevelopmental conditions across the country.

"Rates of ADHD are certainly rising across the Western world and also in Australia," she said.

"We know that there are huge waiting lists … there is a huge gap in the health infrastructure across every jurisdiction in Australia."

Waiting game

Ms Jackson said it would be a big advantage if Ayla could be diagnosed as soon as possible.

"Just having the knowledge that she does have ADHD, it means that the teacher's unconscious bias is lifted," she said.

"Without that they just get labelled as the difficult child in class … it's about awareness."

Ms Jackson said an early diagnosis would allow Ayla, who already struggles with transitions in kindergarten, to fulfil her potential at school.

Sarah Jackson feels an early diagnosis would allow Ayla to achieve her potential. (ABC News)

"It would allow me and the school to then put scaffolding in place for her, so she doesn't fall behind," she said.

"The older that they get, the harder it is for them to have to catch up."

title: ‘Betrayal’: Custodian threatens legal action over Woodside gas approval
text:
A Murujuga traditional custodian is threatening legal action against the federal government, after it approved the extension of Australia's biggest gas project, Woodside's North West Shelf, until 2070.

On Friday, Environment Minister Murray Watt granted the project final approval, almost four months after he gave Woodside 10 days to respond to his provisional approval for the extension.

The approval is subject to 48 strict conditions, including reducing certain gas emissions by 2030, aimed at protecting nearby ancient Indigenous rock art.

The life of the North West Shelf gas project has been extended for another 40 years. (ABC News: Charlie Mclean)

Mardathoonera woman and Murujuga traditional custodian Raelene Cooper described the approval as a "betrayal" to Aboriginal people.

"I have already instructed my lawyers to put the Minister on notice that this decision may have breached his statutory duties and international legal obligations," she said.

She said the conditions placed on the project were no better than those that already existed.

Mr Watt said on Friday the 48 conditions would "avoid and mitigate" significant impacts to the ancient Murujuga rock art in the region, which is adjacent to the gas plant.

Can Australia be both a gas giant and a climate leader? Photo shows Two flares from a tower light up the night sky. Seven years after it was first mooted, the extension of Australia's biggest gas project could not have landed at a more critical juncture for the nation's climate credentials.

But Ms Cooper said the conditions did not go far enough.

"There could be 100 [conditions] from our West Australian and Australian government … I can tell you very confidently those [conditions] aren't nearly enough," she said.

The Murujuga site contains the world's largest collection of ancient rock art. (ABC News: Alistair Bates)

Ms Cooper said Mr Watt's decision to exempt all "industrial gaseous emissions" was offensive and would allow industry to continue damaging the rock art.

"This was not a recommendation from the department, or the independent expert report, or part of the initial UNESCO World Heritage recommendations the government lobbied against.

" … If there is no damage occurring, why is this exemption required? "

Ms Cooper has spent years fighting for the protection of the rock art in northern WA and in 2022 lodged an application under the Aboriginal Heritage Protection Act (AHPA) over fears three nearby industrial projects, including the North West Shelf, were accelerating the degradation of the World Heritage-listed rock art.

Ms Cooper said the federal government's North West Shelf extension approval was a betrayal of Aboriginal people, elders and all Australians.

Have something to share with the ABC's WA newsroom? Photo shows Perth City and Claisebrook Cove Whether it's an image, video, story, or tip-off, you can send it to the ABC's West Australian newsroom here.

But some Indigenous groups welcomed the approval.

Peter Hicks, chair of the Murujuga Aboriginal Corporation said it provided “an even clearer way forward and we thank the Federal Government for enacting a critical part of Australia's legislative framework to ensure that this sacred place is protected in perpetuity,"

'Critical role' for gas

Chamber of Commerce and Industry WA chief economist Aaron Morey, who will soon take the chief executive role in the Chamber of Minerals and Energy WA, also welcomed the extension.

"Gas is going to play a critical role in our energy transition and supporting new renewable technologies, it's also really important to our manufacturing sector and for keeping prices down for households," he said.

"So we think that's the right decision and we welcome the government's decision making and consultation on that issue."

Have something to share with the ABC's WA newsroom? Photo shows Perth City and Claisebrook Cove Whether it's an image, video, story, or tip-off, you can send it to the ABC's West Australian newsroom here.

In a statement, Woodside's chief operating officer Liz Westcott said the project's approval provided certainty for ongoing operations.

"Over this time, the North West Shelf Project has paid more than A$40 billion in royalties and excise, supported thousands of Australian jobs and contributed well over A$300 million to communities in the Pilbara through social investment initiatives and infrastructure support," she said.

Ms Westcott said the decision had followed an "extensive assessment and appeal process", with conditions that would protect cultural heritage.

title: Live: ANZ hit with $240m fine for 'unconscionable' conduct, ASX opens lower
text:
NAB head of FX research Ray Attrill has an interesting note out this morning on the recent rise of the Australian dollar, and not just against the Greenback.

Last week the little Aussie battler gained against all G10 currencies with the exception of Norway's less liquid Krona, which was given a leg up by higher oil prices.

"In an FX (foreign exchange) market that has been rediscovering its enthusiasm to sell the USD ahead of an expected resumption of the Fed easing cycle — AUD ($A) has to some extent been in demand by default," Mr Attrill said.

Traders appear to be shying away from the likes of the Euro and UK pound given the well-ventilated fiscal and political concerns — high public debt across the UK and Europe and a crumbling French government, while the Canadian dollar (aka the Loonie) is being weighed down by the prospect of a rate cut this week.

"At the same time, iron ore prices holding on to the move above $105 a tonne, ongoing gold price appreciation, a falling USD/CNY (Chinese yuan) and an economy that looks to have positive momentum out of what was a strong Q2, are offering plenty of reasons for liking AUD in its own right," Mr Attrill said.

Mr Attrill also noted that a lot of the record speculative short bets against the Aussie dollar on the International Monetary Market are being unwound too, which is supporting the rally.

AMP head of investment strategy Shane Oliver says the US Federal Reserve's likely resumption of rate cuts is positive for the Australian dollar and will marginally increase pressure on the RBA for more rate cuts.

"Money markets now see the Fed cutting by more than the RBA which will push US short term rates below the RBA's cash rate," Dr Oliver said. "Historically, a rising gap between Australian and US rates has tended to see a rising trend in the Australian dollar and its break above $US0.66 may be a tentative sign that it is moving higher. "It's also undervalued versus the $US (with fair value around $US0.73) supporting more upside."

Dr Oliver said if the $A heads significantly higher this may add pressure on the RBA to cut by more than the market is expecting because a rising $A will dampen local growth and inflation.

title: Mid-season upsets shake up AFLW ladder
text:
Fortunes can change very quickly in the AFLW.

After Geelong lost their opening two games, senior coach Dan Lowther said it was well publicised in the short 12-round season that early wins were important, but "who's to say we can't win the next 10?".

That was pretty quickly proven not possible when the Cats went down to Sydney the following week by less than a goal.

But Lowther's argument was strengthened this weekend when his side claimed its second consecutive win, a 30-point hammering over Richmond, rocketing it up the ladder to 10th spot, just outside the top eight and equal on points with reigning grand finalist Brisbane.

Georgie Prespakis has been a key part of the Cats' consecutive wins. (Getty: Kelly Defina)

The fixture structure — where ladder positions from the previous year dictate the difficulty of clubs' run — can deceive how well teams are placed after just a few rounds.

This was highlighted by commentator Abbey Holmes, who said Geelong "have a tough start".

"But it does seem like they are starting to find their groove," Holmes said on Seven.

One of the keys to those consecutive wins was the performance of midfield star Georgie Prespakis.

"Just her ability to link up. Mikayla Bowen's having an unbelievable year as well but just the one-two efforts, the third efforts, the fourth efforts, she never stops running, never stops competing," Holmes said.

"[She] had 31 disposals, 413 metres gained, six clearances — and it's a very big reason as to why the Cats have got consecutive wins on the board now."

North Melbourne are the only side left undefeated in the AFLW after round five. (Getty: Michael Willson/AFL Photos)

After the weekend of upsets, the only team left undefeated are, fairly unsurprisingly, reigning premiers North Melbourne.

They became the first defending premiers to win a grand final rematch in the history of the competition. In toppling Brisbane, they extended their 17-match, 651-day winning streak.

The result puts the Lions, the second-most-successful team in the history of the competition, behind Adelaide, outside the eight in ninth position.

"This isn't the Brisbane Lions that we know. Who's hungry? Who wants the footy? Who wants to put their head over it and win a contested ball?" Holmes asked on Fox during the third quarter.

"It's something that has made them such a dominant side in this competition for a long period of time and it seems to be lacking."

Inaugural Blue hopes for finals berth after hot start Photo shows Carlton players celebrate during a match against Gold Coast. Inaugural Carlton player Gab Pound says the club has reached a turning point after not making the finals since the 2020 COVID-interrupted season.

At the same time, Adelaide, who had just the two wins under their belt coming into the weekend, defeated the previously undefeated Hawthorn.

The Crows did not just run out the victory, but did so by 21 points.

Commentator Jessica Webster told Fox it was a "reminder that the Crows are still a contender" despite a patchy start to the year.

Melbourne, who were also undefeated ahead of the round, fell to Port Adelaide by a mere two points.

Similar to Geelong, St Kilda headed into the weekend with just the one win but had a comprehensive 52-point win over Essendon spearheaded by goalscorer Jesse Wardlaw.

That victory saw them climb to 12th, just ahead of Collingwood, who had a surprise win over previously undefeated Sydney to begin the round.

The other NSW side, GWS, however, broke a 378-day winning drought when they secured a 21-point over the Western Bulldogs after Georgia Garnett starred with three goals.

It leaves just Richmond yet without a win this year.

To close out the round over in the West, Fremantle (14th) denied West Coast (seventh) a first derby win to take their tally over their rivals to 7-0.

It was a game the Dockers came into on a three-game losing run, while the Eagles had only dropped one game all season.

title: Trump’s assault on the Fed has reached boiling point
text:
The Miran appointment, while certain to be rubber-stamped by the Republican majority in the Senate, is controversial because he has said he won’t resign from his role as chair of Trump’s Council of Economic Advisers, instead taking an unpaid leave of absence. Miran was nominated to fill the remaining term of former governor Adriana Kugler, who resigned last month, even though her term wasn’t scheduled to end until January 31 next year. It is unclear if he will remain on the board beyond that date. Trump is still trying to fire Cook on the basis of an allegation made on social media that hasn’t been proven and now appears to have been disproved. Credit: AP By remaining a key Trump adviser while serving as a governor, Miran, regarded as the architect of the administration’s more contentious economic policies – including the tariffs and Trump’s efforts to bring the Fed under the administration’s control – would not be an independent in an institution that Congress designed to be independent of politics. Unlike Waller or Bowman, appointed by Trump but not part of the administration (although Waller is on the short list to be the next Fed chair and therefore wouldn’t want to be offside with Trump), he’d clearly be Trump’s main man inside the Fed.

The Cook affair is also tainted. Trump purported to fire her last month, via a social media post, after the head of the Federal Housing Finance Agency, Bill Pulte, alleged (in a social media post, of course) that she had named two separate properties as her principal place of residence in loan documents, which may have enabled her to borrow more cheaply. Loading She’s not been charged with anything and can only be sacked “for cause,” which is generally thought to mean that the official has done something seriously wrong while in office. The initial judgment that the administration is appealing was that Trump’s justification for firing Cooke didn’t meet the threshold for sufficient cause, in part because the alleged actions occurred before she was a governor. As it happens, what Pulte and Trump have alleged may not even have occurred.

First Reuters, and then a string of major media outlets, have said Cook described her second property as “a vacation home,” not as her principal place of residence, in loan documents they have seen. Cook’s lawyers have said any errors in the loan documents, if there were errors, were unintentional and might be the results of clerical errors. If the documents Reuters and others have sighted – which appear to be loan estimates provided by a credit union – exist then, regardless of what the final loan documents showed, the lender would have been aware that the loan was for a holiday home, not as her primary residence. In other words, Trump is still trying to fire Cook on the basis of an allegation made on social media that hasn’t been proven and now appears to have been disproved. The allegations are a pretext to try to open another spot on the Fed board for a Trump appointee. If Trump can gain a majority of the seven-person board, he would then be in a position to remake the FOMC, where the remaining members are the president of the New York Fed and the presidents of four of the Fed’s 12 regional banks, who serve on a rotating basis. The Fed’s board can veto those appointments.

The White House, with a president who has said he wants the federal funds rate cut by three percentage points, would be able to dictate US monetary policy, ending three quarters of a century of the US central bank’s independence. When the Fed last met, in July, for the first time in more than 30 years there were two governors – Waller and Bowman – who dissented from the majority’s decision to hold rates steady. The interest this week will be in whether Miran, Waller and Bowman, argue for something more than the 25 basis points cut expected. The majority is likely to be conservative – there could be some who argue for rates to remain on hold – because, while the jobs market appears to be shrinking and the unemployment rate is rising, the full effects of Trump’s tariffs are yet to show up in the data. That’s because of the on-off-on way they were implemented, which allowed companies to build up inventories of goods before the tariffs took effect. With the main “reciprocal” tariffs finally going live last month, their impact on prices will progressively show up over the rest of this year and beyond. The worst-case outlook for the Fed is one of stagflation: low economic growth, or even a recession, while the inflation rate remains high. Trump’s trade wars and his immigration policies make it possible that there could be, simultaneously, rising unemployment and rising inflation.

title: Australia news LIVE: Polling shows support for Coalition has plummeted to new low; Kirk suspect not cooperating with authorities, says Utah governor
text:
Climate Change Minister Chris Bowen has defined climate change’s ongoing impact on Australia as “cascading”, “compounding” and “concurrent”, as the government releases the first National Climate Risk Assessment report.

“Cascading. It will get worse. Over time. Compounding its impact on climate change by making other impacts worse. And concurrent, communities will suffer the impacts of climate change in different ways at the same time. And we will have a lot to manage,” Bowen told a press conference in Parliament House.

“One thing that is very clear from this climate assessment is that a whole country has a lot at stake. Every Australian regardless whether they live has a lot at stake. But the report does make clear that some communities have a particular amount of stake,” Bowen said.

The minister said climate change would particularly impact Queensland, New South Wales, the ACT and Tasmania — as well as those living in regional and rural Australia.

title: The Guardian finally lands its new political editor
text:
The Guardian has concluded its long-running search for a political editor, promoting its chief political correspondent Tom McIlroy, who joined the outlet this year in the lead up to the federal election.

McIlroy’s appointment means the Australian outpost of the British newspaper will now begin a search for a new chief political correspondent.

It also shifts the focus for Guardian Australia after a period of tumult for its Canberra bureau. The political editor position had been vacant after changes to the bureau led to an exodus of its top talent and an internal HR investigation.

Former Financial Review journalist Tom McIlroy has emerged as The Guardian’s political editor Credit: Oscar Colman

In late 2024, Canberra-based Guardian staff were interviewed as part of an HR investigation after political editor Karen Middleton made a complaint against the outlet’s chief political correspondent Paul Karp, who lodged a counter-claim against Middleton.

title: Ref rage generated a crackling atmosphere in Sydney. But it also taught the Wallabies valuable lessons
text:
They defended stoutly and got the job done. But even 30 minutes later, a gobsmacked Contepomi couldn’t bring himself to wave it away with an “all’s well than ends well”. “It’s frustrating. I think we don’t deserve that. So I’ve got mixed emotions. It’s very frustrating, because it’s not working. It’s as simple as that. It’s not working. The system, whatever they are doing to get it better, there’s no consistency and it’s not working.” Rounding out the strange day, the Wallabies - the losing team who been caned 14-7 and had every right to pour fuel on the same bonfire - then came in and bit their tongues. Referee Christophe Ridley gestures to Harry Wilson. Credit: Getty Images Showing his years of experience, Joe Schmidt rattled off half-a-dozen things he’d observed but surmised they couldn’t worry about it. It was the wise approach, for a bunch of reasons. Referees are like elephants, and you’ll get them again.

But it’s fair to say the referee and the match officials, to put it mildly, had a rough day. Ridley is an inexperienced young Test referee and, as can occur, his attempts to stamp authority early on for minor stuff set in motion a game that may have got away from him. He then didn’t stay consistent, which irked the captains, and when new penalties in key moments were found from areas he’d previously ignored - like high shots and obstruction by retreating defenders - the captains’ grumbles spread out and into a very restless home crowd. Santiago Carreras kicks a goal for Argentina. Credit: Getty Images In many ways, it made for brilliant theatre. With a record crowd (post-rebuild), the joint was absolutely rocking. Nothing brings people together more than booing a referee whose calls they don’t agree with. In the end, all the match officials were so rattled they were the only four people in the stadium who missed, or cleared, a blatant forward pass. Even Wallabies players had their hands on their heads, missed-soccer-goal style.

The game ended in a loss for the Wallabies but oddly enough, the crackling atmosphere was arguably one of the best in years, possibly decades. With unprecedented numbers of people in generations of gold jerseys, old and new, and with lots of kids in the stands, the sense of injustice only served to unite - and amplify - the support. Loading Pubs and restaurants around Paddington and Surry Hills did a roaring trade of post-game analysis. And, also encouragingly, most Aussie fans agreed the end result was the right one. For all the harsh calls on the Wallabies, the Pumas had still been the better side on the day; hungrier and cleaner in most contests, and certainly more physical. The Wallabies mostly had themselves to blame. After getting that dangerous taste of space early - Joseph-Aukuso Suaalii’s fifth-minute try came after the Wallabies had gone backwards with their carrying - the home team then frantically chased even more quick kills.

Wallabies players spoke post-game about the need to fix up their discipline, having gone from 10 Tests in two Tests in South Africa to 25 in two clashes with Argentina. And patience and belief in teammates is usually the antidote to cutting penalty counts. But patience also the key to being more clinical, a bit more boring and winning a game like the one at Allianz Stadium. “We’ve been really efficient off our line breaks, but probably the last two weeks we’ve tried to score off those line breaks as opposed to the patience of,” Tate McDermott said. “We’ve got to weigh up whether the risk is actually worth the reward there.” For all the Australian fury at the referee team, the takeaway for the Wallabies is Contepomi was fuming too. Short of World Rugby doing the logical thing and using top Test referees for all top Tests, no matter their nationality (Angus Gardner was wasted as a touch judge in Wellington, for example), rookie refs will inevitably be inconsistent as they build experience.

title: Local buyer splashes $12.35m on Tamarama home with a ‘better view’
text:
An eastern suburbs’ buyer, upsizing in the same suburb of Tamarama, paid $12.35 million for a home with a “better view” at auction on Saturday.

The five-bedroom, four-storey ocean view property at 27 Carlisle Street drew a crowd of 80 to the house with easy access to the beach.

Three registered, and two actively bid for the home guided at $11.25 million. Bidding opened at $11.5 million and rose in steady increments to $12 million until it sold under the hammer at its reserve of $12.35 million.

There is no legal requirement for a vendor’s reserve to be in line with their property’s price guide.
